California’s Phaseout of MTBE - Background and Current Status
California’s Phaseout of MTBE - Background
and Current Status

UC TSR&TP Advisory Committee Spring Meeting Cal EPA, Sacramento March 17, 2003
UC TSR&TP Advisory Committee Spring Meeting
Cal EPA, Sacramento
March 17, 2003

Gordon Schremp California Energy Commission gschremp@energy.state.ca.us
Gordon Schremp
California Energy Commission
gschremp@energy.state.ca.us

Introduction
Introduction

Background - history of MTBE use Factors associated with decision to phase out the use of MTBE Subsequent Actions (1999-2003) Elements necessary for successful phaseout Anticipated impacts of MTBE removal Other issues affecting California Study to examine causes of today’s high prices Closing remarks

Factors associated with decision to phase out
the use of MTBE

Background - MTBE Use
Background - MTBE Use

MTBE used in gasoline since late 1970s Required seasonal use beginning 1992 – Winter oxygenated fuels program – Designed to reduce carbon monoxide emissions – Most refiners selected MTBE – Approximately 11 percent of gasoline volume Mandated year-round use in 1995 & 1996 – Reformulated gasoline (RFG) program to control emissions of toxics and pollutants that contribute to the formation of photochemical smog
MTBE used in gasoline since late 1970s
Required seasonal use beginning 1992
– Winter oxygenated fuels program
– Designed to reduce carbon monoxide emissions
– Most refiners selected MTBE
– Approximately 11 percent of gasoline volume
Mandated year-round use in 1995 & 1996
– Reformulated gasoline (RFG) program to control
emissions of toxics and pollutants that contribute
to the formation of photochemical smog

– Federal law requires minimum use of oxygenates
– Federal law requires minimum use of oxygenates

in all RFG regions (2 percent by weight)
in all RFG regions (2 percent by weight)

– California regulations permit discretionary use, but 3
– California regulations permit discretionary use, but
3

federal mandate applies to 80 percent of State
federal mandate applies to 80 percent of State

Background - MTBE Use (cont.)
Background - MTBE Use (cont.)

Gasoline demand and supply – Gasoline demand in California during 2003
Gasoline demand and supply
– Gasoline demand in California during 2003

estimated in range of 15.6 to 16 billion gallons – Demand expected to increase between 1.6 and 3
estimated in range of 15.6 to 16 billion gallons
– Demand expected to increase between 1.6 and 3

percent per year
percent per year

– Refineries located in California produce the
– Refineries located in California produce the

majority of gasoline for the State
majority of gasoline for the State

– Imports of gasoline and blending components increase each year, while refinery capacity remains relatively flat (annual growth rate of 0.5 percent)
– Imports of gasoline and blending components
increase each year, while refinery capacity
remains relatively flat (annual growth rate of 0.5
percent)

– California represents nearly 12 percent of United
– California represents nearly 12 percent of United

States gasoline demand
States gasoline demand

Background - MTBE Use (cont.)
Background - MTBE Use (cont.)

Types and quantities of fuel oxygenates – MTBE is primary oxygenate of choice
Types and quantities of fuel oxygenates
– MTBE is primary oxygenate of choice

• Superior blending properties
• Superior blending properties

– 1.4 billion gallons blended in California gasoline
– 1.4 billion gallons blended in California gasoline

during 2002
during 2002

– Blending concentration of over 9 volume percent
– Blending concentration of over 9 volume percent

for entire gasoline pool
for entire gasoline pool

– Ethanol use in 2002 less than 100 million gallons • ConocoPhillips was first company to use ethanol in
– Ethanol use in 2002 less than 100 million gallons
• ConocoPhillips was first company to use ethanol in

California reformulated gasoline
California reformulated gasoline

MTBE concentration declining over time
MTBE concentration declining over time

Factors Associated with Decision to Phase Out the Use of MTBE
Factors Associated with Decision to
Phase Out the Use of MTBE

Water resource contamination concerns – Detections of MTBE in water wells – Prediction that contamination would spread and
Water resource contamination concerns
– Detections of MTBE in water wells
– Prediction that contamination would spread and

cleanup costs dramatically increase Potential health concerns also raised Studies ordered by California Legislature to determine: – Cost to eliminate MTBE – Assess risk to people and the environment of
cleanup costs dramatically increase
Potential health concerns also raised
Studies ordered by California Legislature to
determine:
– Cost to eliminate MTBE
– Assess risk to people and the environment of

continued use
continued use

– Initial work conducted by California Energy Commission and University of California
– Initial work conducted by California Energy
Commission and University of California

Factors Associated with Decision to Phase Out the Use of MTBE (cont.)
Factors Associated with Decision to
Phase Out the Use of MTBE (cont.)

Initial studies completed by late 1998 – UC - Annual water remediation costs estimated at
Initial studies completed by late 1998
– UC - Annual water remediation costs estimated at

$340 MM to $1.5 billion
$340 MM to $1.5 billion

– CEC - Gasoline production cost would only
– CEC - Gasoline production cost would only

increase 2 - 3 cents per gallon with use of ethanol • Annual cost to California consumers of $300 to $450
increase 2 - 3 cents per gallon with use of ethanol
• Annual cost to California consumers of $300 to $450

million
million

Executive Order issued by Governor Davis during March 1999 – Phases out use of MTBE by December 31, 2002 – California Air Resources Board (ARB) amends gasoline specifications banning MTBE, ethanol only acceptable fuel oxygenate substitute
Executive Order issued by Governor Davis
during March 1999
– Phases out use of MTBE by December 31, 2002
– California Air Resources Board (ARB) amends
gasoline specifications banning MTBE, ethanol
only acceptable fuel oxygenate substitute

Subsequent Actions - 1999
Subsequent Actions - 1999

Energy Commission determines that timetable to remove MTBE cannot be advanced ARB adopts Phase 3 RFG regulations – Ethanol only permissible oxygenate – Gasoline specifications changed • lowers sulfur from 40 to 20 ppm • lowers benzene from 1.0 to 0.8 vol. percent • aromatics limit increased from 30 to 35 vol. percent • distillation (T50 and T90) increased by 3 to 5 degrees F. • olefins unchanged
Energy Commission determines that
timetable to remove MTBE cannot be
advanced
ARB adopts Phase 3 RFG regulations
– Ethanol only permissible oxygenate
– Gasoline specifications changed
• lowers sulfur from 40 to 20 ppm
• lowers benzene from 1.0 to 0.8 vol. percent
• aromatics limit increased from 30 to 35 vol. percent
• distillation (T50 and T90) increased by 3 to 5 degrees F.
• olefins unchanged

Subsequent Actions - 2001
Subsequent Actions - 2001

US EPA denies request by California to receive waiver from the federal minimum oxygen requirement - June 12 – 70 percent of State’s gasoline must contain an
US EPA denies request by California to
receive waiver from the federal minimum
oxygen requirement - June 12
– 70 percent of State’s gasoline must contain an

oxygenate - increases to 80 % by 2003 – Failure to issue waiver will cost California
oxygenate - increases to 80 % by 2003
– Failure to issue waiver will cost California

consumers at least an additional 3 cents per gallon or $475 million per year
consumers at least an additional 3 cents per c o n s u m e r s
a t
l e a s t
a n
a d d i t i o n a l 3
c e n t s
p e r
gallon or $475 million per year

California Air Resources Board sues US EPA to obtain waiver - August 13 – Final arguments heard in Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals (February 2003) - awaiting decision
California Air Resources Board sues US EPA
to obtain waiver - August 13
– Final arguments heard in Ninth Circuit Court of
Appeals (February 2003) - awaiting decision

Subsequent Actions - 2002
Subsequent Actions - 2002

CEC revised estimates for MTBE phaseout – 3.4 to 6.4 cents per gallon – $540 MM to $1 billion per year Stillwater Report raised supply and infrastructure concerns – Estimated 5 to 10 percent decline in gasoline supply and increased potential for price spikes
CEC revised estimates for MTBE phaseout
– 3.4 to 6.4 cents per gallon
– $540 MM to $1 billion per year
Stillwater Report raised supply and
infrastructure concerns
– Estimated 5 to 10 percent decline in gasoline
supply and increased potential for price spikes

Legal action by Lake Tahoe utility – Several companies sued for MTBE contamination – Finding of “defective product” by jury – Settlement for $68 million
Legal action by Lake Tahoe utility
– Several companies sued for MTBE contamination
– Finding of “defective product” by jury
– Settlement for $68 million

Subsequent Actions - 2002 (cont.)
Subsequent Actions - 2002 (cont.)

Governor Davis issues Exec. Order D-52-02 – MTBE phaseout delayed until January 1, 2004 A number of refining companies announce early phaseout of MTBE in California – BP, ChevronTexaco, ExxonMobil, and Shell plan to
Governor Davis issues Exec. Order D-52-02
– MTBE phaseout delayed until January 1, 2004
A number of refining companies announce
early phaseout of MTBE in California
– BP, ChevronTexaco, ExxonMobil, and Shell plan to

eliminate use of MTBE by early 2003
eliminate use of MTBE by early 2003

– The refineries operated by these companies
– The refineries operated by these companies

required less modifications & more self-sufficient with regard to their distribution infrastructure – Including Phillips, 60-70 percent of California’s
required less modifications & more self-sufficient
with regard to their distribution infrastructure
– Including Phillips, 60-70 percent of California’s

gasoline will contain ethanol during 2003
gasoline will contain ethanol during 2003

ARB amends gasoline regulations to delay implementation date until the end of 2003
ARB amends gasoline regulations to delay
implementation date until the end of 2003

California Refinery Status - 2003
California Refinery Status - 2003

Majority of Southern Calif. production MTBE- free, less than 50 percent in Northern Calif.
Majority of Southern Calif. production MTBE-
free, less than 50 percent in Northern Calif.

Elements Necessary for a Successful MTBE Phaseout
Elements Necessary for a Successful
MTBE Phaseout

Ethanol supplies must be adequate Ethanol logistics must be in place Refinery modifications must be completed Gasoline supply (imports) must be available Import infrastructure must be sufficient to accommodate anticipated increase in imports “Successful” means that transition to ethanol occurs without disruption to the market and minimal impact on consumers and the economy
Ethanol supplies must be adequate
Ethanol logistics must be in place
Refinery modifications must be completed
Gasoline supply (imports) must be available
Import infrastructure must be sufficient to
accommodate anticipated increase in imports
“Successful” means that transition to ethanol
occurs without disruption to the market and
minimal impact on consumers and the
economy

Anticipated Impacts of MTBE Removal
Anticipated Impacts of MTBE Removal

Demand for ethanol will increase – Calif. will require significant quantities of ethanol
Demand for ethanol will increase
– Calif. will require significant quantities of ethanol

• 560 to 580 million gallons by 2003 • 760 to 990 million gallons by 2004
• 560 to 580 million gallons by 2003
• 760 to 990 million gallons by 2004

– Current US ethanol production capacity approximately 3 billion gallons per year
– Current US ethanol production capacity
approximately 3 billion gallons per year

– Energy Commission survey (December 2002) of ethanol industry concludes that supply should be sufficient to meet California’s incremental ethanol demand
– Energy Commission survey (December 2002) of
ethanol industry concludes that supply should be
sufficient to meet California’s incremental ethanol
demand

Ethanol Survey Update
Ethanol Survey Update

Survey Results - U.S. Ethanol Production Capacity (MM Gallons)
Survey Results - U.S. Ethanol
Production Capacity (MM Gallons)

Anticipated Impacts (cont.)
Anticipated Impacts (cont.)

Ethanol Logistics – Ethanol supplies will be delivered to California via
Ethanol Logistics
– Ethanol supplies will be delivered to California via

rail and marine vessel
rail and marine vessel

– Ethanol is delivered to main staging areas before
– Ethanol is delivered to main staging areas before

being trucked to gasoline terminals
being trucked to gasoline terminals

– Modifications nearing completion to allow terminal
– Modifications nearing completion to allow terminal

in Southern California to receive “unit trains” – Remaining terminal modifications scheduled for
in Southern California to receive “unit trains”
– Remaining terminal modifications scheduled for

completion later this year
completion later this year

– Large shipments of ethanol began to arrive in
– Large shipments of ethanol began to arrive in

California during December of 2002
California during December of 2002

– Refiners will try and keep ethanol inventories at
– Refiners will try and keep ethanol inventories at

high levels as a hedge against a potential interruption of deliveries
high levels as a hedge against a potential
interruption of deliveries

Ethanol Sources and Transportation
Ethanol Sources and Transportation

Midwest Supply - Majority of Supply to California
Midwest Supply - Majority of Supply to California

European Supply
European Supply

Oregon Terminals
Oregon
Terminals

SF Bay Refineries
SF Bay
Refineries

Los Angeles Refineries
Los Angeles
Refineries

Not shown: Central California Refineries (Bakersfield)
Not shown: Central
California Refineries
(Bakersfield)

Caribbean Supply
Caribbean Supply

Brazilian Supply
Brazilian Supply

Anticipated Impacts (cont.)
Anticipated Impacts (cont.)

Reformulated gasoline production from California refineries will decline – Gasoline with MTBE at 11 vol. percent – Refiners must remove additional 5 percent of
Reformulated gasoline production from
California refineries will decline
– Gasoline with MTBE at 11 vol. percent
– Refiners must remove additional 5 percent of

gasoline components prior to blending ethanol to avoid violation of volatility standards (Rvp)
gasoline components prior to blending ethanol to
avoid violation of volatility standards (Rvp)

– Ethanol blended at nearly 6 vol. percent – Absent any other adjustments, gasoline
– Ethanol blended at nearly 6 vol. percent
– Absent any other adjustments, gasoline

production would decrease by 10 percent
production would decrease by 10 percent

– But some refiners have:
– But some refiners have:

• Increased alkylate production, imported more blending components, converted some conventional gasoline to RFG & delayed transition away from MTBE
• Increased alkylate production, imported more blending
components, converted some conventional gasoline to
RFG & delayed transition away from MTBE

– Summer 2003 production decline about 1 to 2 %
– Summer 2003 production decline about 1 to 2 %

Anticipated Impacts (cont.)
Anticipated Impacts (cont.)

Imported components will have to increase – Production decline of 1 to 2 percent equates to a
Imported components will have to increase
– Production decline of 1 to 2 percent equates to a

daily volume of 10-20 thousand barrels
daily volume of 10-20 thousand barrels

– Coupled with an expected demand increase of 1.6
– Coupled with an expected demand increase of 1.6

to 3 percent, an additional 26 to 50 thousand barrels per day of blending components will be required to provide adequate gasoline supplies
to 3 percent, an additional 26 to 50 thousand
barrels per day of blending components will be
required to provide adequate gasoline supplies

– Phase 3 RFG for ethanol blending is a more
– Phase 3 RFG for ethanol blending is a more

difficult formulation to produce for refiners outside the US
difficult formulation to produce for refiners outside
the US

• A number of the foreign refiners who produced summer
• A number of the foreign refiners who produced summer

grade Phase 2 RFG do not consistently produce Phase 3 RFG for ethanol blending at their facilities
grade Phase 2 RFG do not consistently produce Phase 3
RFG for ethanol blending at their facilities

• 2 refiners have sent cargoes of the new summer RFG,
• 2 refiners have sent cargoes of the new summer RFG,

but the ships have yet to arrive
but the ships have yet to arrive

Anticipated Impacts (cont.)
Anticipated Impacts (cont.)

Logistics – Marine logistics infrastructure already strained
Logistics
– Marine logistics infrastructure already strained

• tank storage capacity scarce
• tank storage capacity scarce

– Ability of system to smoothly accommodate additional volume and segregation needs is greatest concern in California
– Ability of system to smoothly accommodate
additional volume and segregation needs is
greatest concern in California

• Recent price increases in California are partially a result
• Recent price increases in California are partially a result

of a strained system
of a strained system

– Marine infrastructure study underway by Stillwater
– Marine infrastructure study underway by Stillwater

Associates to be released in April
Associates to be released in April

Other Issues Affecting California
Other Issues Affecting California

National energy legislation - under debate – Renewable fuel standard (RFS)
National energy legislation - under debate
– Renewable fuel standard (RFS)

• Adoption of RFS could significantly increase demand for ethanol, potentially straining supplies, unless “planned” capacity expansions receive funding and complete construction per announced schedules
• Adoption of RFS could significantly increase demand for
ethanol, potentially straining supplies, unless “planned”
capacity expansions receive funding and complete
construction per announced schedules

• Elimination of Federal oxygen requirement could help, but California is still expected to require significant amounts of ethanol regardless of the minimum oxygen requirement
• Elimination of Federal oxygen requirement could help,
but California is still expected to require significant
amounts of ethanol regardless of the minimum oxygen
requirement

– National MTBE phaseout
– National MTBE phaseout

• Mandatory elimination of MTBE in rest of country would
• Mandatory elimination of MTBE in rest of country would

decrease gasoline supplies in the US
decrease gasoline supplies in the US

• Demand for clean blending components to replace lost
• Demand for clean blending components to replace lost

volume would increase
volume would increase

• Sources from outside the US could command higher
• Sources from outside the US could command higher

values
values

Other Issues (cont.)
Other Issues (cont.)

Regional MTBE bans – CT scheduled to phaseout MTBE by October 1,
Regional MTBE bans
– CT scheduled to phaseout MTBE by October 1,

but their legislature is considering a delay
but their legislature is considering a delay

– NY scheduled for end of year, rest of Northeast
– NY scheduled for end of year, rest of Northeast

may or may not follow
may or may not follow

– Decreased availability of supplies cited by ESAI – NYMEX has also raised concerns about potential
– Decreased availability of supplies cited by ESAI
– NYMEX has also raised concerns about potential

impact on the futures markets if multiple fuels
impact on the futures markets if multiple fuels

• NY harbor is delivery point for futures contracts which
• NY harbor is delivery point for futures contracts which

specify federal RFG containing MTBE
specify federal RFG containing MTBE

• No plans to offer futures contracts for RFG containing
• No plans to offer futures contracts for RFG containing

ethanol
ethanol

• Fewer contracts, less hedging opportunities and resulting
• Fewer contracts, less hedging opportunities and resulting

increased volatility of gasoline prices in the region
increased volatility of gasoline prices in the region

Other Issues (cont.)
Other Issues (cont.)

Cleaner fuel standards for gasoline and diesel fuel – Lower sulfur levels for gasoline and diesel fuel in the US may lead to further refinery consolidation
Cleaner fuel standards for gasoline and
diesel fuel
– Lower sulfur levels for gasoline and diesel fuel in
the US may lead to further refinery consolidation

• Additional need to import cleaner components Stricter fuel standards in other countries – Competition for clean components will increase unless refinery capacity expansions keep pace with growing demand
• Additional need to import cleaner components
Stricter fuel standards in other countries
– Competition for clean components will increase
unless refinery capacity expansions keep pace
with growing demand

Reduction of contributions to federal highway account – Use of ethanol reduces federal excise tax – California contributions will decline significantly
Reduction of contributions to federal highway
account
– Use of ethanol reduces federal excise tax
– California contributions will decline significantly

Ethanol Use Reduces Federal Excise Tax
Ethanol Use Reduces Federal Excise Tax

Ethanol Use Decreases Highway Account Receipts
Ethanol Use Decreases Highway
Account Receipts

Study to Examine Causes of Today’s High Gasoline Prices
Study to Examine Causes of Today’s
High Gasoline Prices

March 14 - Governor Davis orders investigation of high prices – Assessment will include gasoline, diesel fuel,
March 14 - Governor Davis orders
investigation of high prices
– Assessment will include gasoline, diesel fuel,

natural gas and electrical generators – Energy Commission and Public Utilities
natural gas and electrical generators
– Energy Commission and Public Utilities

Commission will conduct analysis – Study to be completed within 15 days
Commission will conduct analysis
– Study to be completed within 15 days

Closing Remarks
Closing Remarks

Transition away from MTBE will be completed later this year Energy Commission will continue to monitor the transition and adequacy of supplies Growing demand for gasoline and anticipated production declines will increase the need to import clean blending components Costs to produce gasoline may be greater on a sustained basis
Transition away from MTBE will be completed
later this year
Energy Commission will continue to monitor
the transition and adequacy of supplies
Growing demand for gasoline and anticipated
production declines will increase the need to
import clean blending components
Costs to produce gasoline may be greater on
a sustained basis
